 free will
  
 -noun
 1.
 free and independent choice; voluntary decision: You took on the responsibility of your own free will.
 2.
 Philosophy . the doctrine that the conduct of human beings expresses personal choice and is not simply determined by physical or divine forces.
 
 
 World English Dictionary
 free will
 
 - n
 1. a. the apparent human ability to make choices that are not externally determined
 b. Compare determinism the doctrine that such human freedom of choice is not illusory
 c. ( as modifier ): a free-will decision
 2. the ability to make a choice without coercion: he left of his own free will: I did not influence him 
 
 Cultural Dictionary
 
 free will definition
 
 The ability to choose, think, and act voluntarily. For many philosophers, to believe in free will is to believe that human beings can be the authors of their own actions and to reject the idea that human actions are determined by external conditions or fate.
 
 Encyclopedia
 
 free will
 
 in humans, the power or capacity to choose among alternatives or to act in certain situations independently of natural, social, or divine restraints. Free will is denied by those who espouse any of various forms of determinism. Arguments for free will are based on the subjective experience of freedom, on sentiments of guilt, on revealed religion, and on the universal supposition of responsibility for personal actions that underlies the concepts of law, reward, punishment, and incentive. In theology, the existence of free will must be reconciled with God's omniscience and goodness (in allowing man to choose badly), and with divine grace, which allegedly is necessary for any meritorious act. A prominent feature of modern Existentialism is the concept of a radical, perpetual, and frequently agonizing freedom of choice. Jean-Paul Sartre, for example, speaks of the individual "condemned to be free" even though his situation may be wholly determined.

I read the article that you posted. Very eloquently written, but not too convincing. The author obviously starts off with the conclusion that free will doesn't exist, the proceeds to justify in a non-linear way why he thinks such is the case. He presents arguments for and against his position, which is a good thing, though he doesn't demonstrate that the counter-arguments clearly win in support of his position. So there are a bunch of loose ends, implying that the issue is far from being settled. Still, in the end, he holds to his foregone conclusion. 
 
 His strongest argument is probably that in order to believe that free will exists as an independent source outside of "programmable" cause and effect, one must characterize free will as a metaphysical abstract that lives in the ether of consciousness and has a process of its own that transcends the laws of physics. He mockingly refers to this as "magical soul" (or something like that). As a rational thinking scientist, magic as an explanation cannot be entertained, so it must be eliminated. Fair enough, if we decide to simplify free will to such a strawman definition.
 
 One classical argument he mentions in support of free will is the question "if free will doesn't exist, how is it possible to believe that it does?" I think this question hits the heart of the issue. If we remove free will, a massive part of our vocabulary must also vanish, as there would be no such thing as should, because, could, will, try, effort and any other term that could possibly express alternative action. There would be no such thing as plan, forecast or expectation. It would be abundantly apparent that our reactions are simply pre-programmed defaults, our existence would be robotic automatons, and consciousness would serve no purpose but to make our existence torturous. If occam's razor would eliminate the "magical soul" from logical existence, why wouldn't consciousness be also eliminated as a function of evolution? Are we also going to conclude that conscious is an illusion as well? The mere fact that we can question the existence of free will and debate its impact speaks volumes in support of it. 
 
 The other point he goes into detail about is the issue of social order and justice. Consequence is the primary motivator of how decisions are made. It is how living things learn, adapt and continue to survive. A baby animal is intimidated by everything that comes at it when its born, but later learns that an approaching leaf results in no ill consequence, but an approaching predator does. If there is a consequence attached to making a decision, it greatly impacts the frequency of that decision. The author argues that this is an aspect of the enviromental factor, not of free will. Of course, he doesn't address the fact that regardless of how many people live in the same environment, where, say, the consequence of commiting murder is life in prison, people still opt to commit murder. However, it is widely agreed, even by those who deny that free will exists, that murder rates are greatly less if there is a consequence involved, than if there is none. 
 
 This brings me to the third major argument: behavioral science. For the life of me I cannot understand how this even passes for a science. We begin with the hypothesis that all behavior is governed by a degree of genetic predisposition, environmental pressure, and a chaotic element of quantum randomness. In other words, all actions are the result of our chemical composition going through the motions of pre-programmed data processing, while our naïve consciousness sits back helplessly to the dictates of fate (fate being the output from the genetic, enviromental and chaotic inputs). So you cannot choose you identity, nor can you control habits, tendencies or preferences. This is a mainstream argument for gay behavior, and yet the same ones that support this idea have no comment when asked about incest or pedophilia. It can be used conveniently, and that makes it appealing. So much for scientific integrity. 
 
 I don't see determinism standing on its own 2 feet from this article. It stands on the weak premise that since we must necessarily remove free will, determinism is the only explanation left. Determinism doesn't even come close to explaining the fact that consciousness exist, and that, contrary to its own thesis, we aren't mindless robots. It doesn't properly address the question of being questioned. And it doesn't address the reality of the value of law and order in soceity. It simply insists that it must be correct because free will is too metaphysical to be true. 
 
 But hey, I'm biased too... (Or am I......)

How can we discuss karma without invoking the metaphysical realm? Traditionally, karma refers to an inner sense of well-being that comes from "good decisions", that projects outward and attracts good events back to you, and vice versa with bad decisions or actions (as in the law of attraction). in a deterministic worldview, we cannot manipulate karma.  From: Karma; The Laws of Cause and Effect
 I will highlight in red the parts that I would omit and blue, what I would add:
 
 In its major conception, karma is the physical, mental and supramental system of neutral rebound, "cause and effect," that is inherent in existence within the bounds of time, space, and causation. Essentially what this means is that the very being which one experiences (say, as a human being) is governed by an immutable preservation of energy, vibration, and action. It is comparable to the Golden Rule but denies the ostenisble arbitrariness of Fate, Destiny, Kismet, or other such Western conceptions by attributing absolute reason and determinism to the workings of the cosmos.(natural Universe)
 
 Karma, for these reasons, naturally implies reincarnation since thoughts and deeds in past lives will affect one's current situation (I would say that our GES affects our lives and omit reincarnation altogether). 
 Thus, humanity (through a sort of collective karma) and individuals alike are responsible for the tragedies and good 'fortunes' which they experience. (along with and limited by outside factors such as mere interaction with everything else that exists in the Universe) 
 The concept of an inscrutable "God" figure is not necessary with the idea of karma. It is vital to note that karma is not an instrument of a god, or a single God, but is rather the physical and spiritual 'physics' of being. As gravity governs the motions of heavenly bodies and objects on the surface of the earth, karma governs the motions and happenings of life, both inanimate and animate, unconscious and conscious, in the cosmic realm. I think 'Karma' can be just another word for 'laws of Nature', plain and simple and forget about this mystical 'cosmic realm'. 
 
 Technically, Karma doesn't fit into my beliefs but, it's edited version does. Just as there are portions of the bible that I consider valid and true but, not all.

Define: destiny dictates everything specifically, destiny.
 

 Under a deterministic model, all actions are reactions to previous actions. Every event is both the effect of preceeding actions, and the cause of subsequent actions, creating a web of cause-effect chain reactions. Since all the factors that go into the resulting event are knowable beforehand, and since the process by which these knowable factors go through is also knowable, then the result can be knowable as well. There are no unpredictable or unknowable factors involved. Therefore, once the input factors are known, the output can be predicted every time. In fact, there is no other possible output than the calculated result. When a calculator is given the input of 3+2, there is not other unknown or unpredictable factors coming into the equation, so the output is predictable. Determinism would follow the same idea. There is only one possible output, and it is a predictable one. And that output becomes an input factor for the next event. The future can be calculated forward to any extent, because there is nothing but knowable data and processing involved. 
 
 Destiny is any inevitable future event that an individual can be involved in. And since all events are inevitable results of previous events, ad infinitum, everything that everyone does is them doing what they were destined to do at the given point in time.

This has been something that is somewhat a thorn in my side that I need to address. Its the popular sentiment that is shared by the author of that article I read, the youtube video guy, and our forum residents sandycane, trebor and gansao. No doubt its quite a popular belief among anyone who subscribes to determinism. That is, free will is an illusion. 
 
 First, by declaring that free will is an illusion, we are admitting that we don't know enough about free will to make a conclusion about it, but are doing so anyway. In fact, to make such a claim is to say that even though it seems as though we have evidence of free will before us, let's believe the opposite instead. 
 
 Second, let's look at the evolutionary implications. Most people can easily accept that animals, lower forms of life, and inanimate objects have no free will, even among those who believe that humans have it. If this is the case, then at some point we adapted a mechanism that gives us a distorted view of reality. Our consciousness is tricking us into believing that something we think is real isn't. As a matter of fact, even our consciousness must be something that we adapted. If we don't make decisions, but rather react in predefined ways to external stimuli, why would a conscience be necessary for survival? Why would we then need to adopt a self-deceiving function in order to compensate for the fact that we have a conscience that doesn't help us function at all? If we cannot consciously control our actions, why does consciousness exist? Or is consciousness itself also an illusion?
 
 Third is the question of whether we can control behavior. For the determinist the answer is no. Interestingly enough, there is a huge concern among determinists that if the world population were taught that free will doesn't exist, people would give themselves liberty to utterly do anything they wanted to, under the claim that they have no control of their actions. The fear is that chaos would abound and all forms of order in our society would disappear. This is actually quite a legitimate fear. So the solution is to continue to let society at large believe that free will exists, and therefore that we have reason to keep a system of law and order in place, and to judge individuals for their own actions. What's interesting is that this is based on the hypothesis that behavior can be controlled if we tell people their behavior can be controlled, but it cannot be controlled if we tell them it cannot be controlled. As far as I see, either an individual can control his own behavior, or he cannot. Why does this fear of chaos in a deterministic world exist?
 
 Finally (and probably my favorite), is the fact that this debate exists. If determinism is the order of the world, wouldn't it be abundantly apparent that our actions are out of our control, and that we cannot will ourselves to do anything? We would be no more than programmable robots, motivated by species continuation, and automatically operating under preset patterns and algorithms. At some point throughout history, we would realise that attempt, effort, plan and desire are all useless, and that what we believe to be voluntary action is really calculated reflexes. The reality is, however, that we are not mindless robots. Not only can we conceive and even simulate alternative actions, but we discover, invent and innovate. We can question options even if we don't select them. We can think independently enough to imagine that we cannot think independently! That says a lot. 
 
 I don't see these issues being addressed. Claiming that free will is an illusion, without even attempting to build a solid case for such a hypothesis, is intellectual laziness if ever there was an instance of it. I'm sure better can be done than that. Its one thing to say that you believe (or in many cases know without doubt) that free will is an illusion. This dogma in the face of evidence to the contrary reminds me of another school of thought I would think that most determinists would have grown out of. Or maybe not....

 1. the faculty of conscious and especially of deliberate action; the power of control the mind has over its own actions: the freedom of the will.

 14. to decide or determine: Others debate, but the king wills.
 -Idiom
 15. at will,
 a. at one's discretion or pleasure; as one desires: to wander at will through the countryside.
 b. at one's disposal or command.

 Consequences are always attached to decisions. They may not always be as severe as life and death, and they may not always involve the consequence being enforced by another person, but consequences are always there. You seem to be saying that free will can only exist if the consequence of the decision is not being enforced by a human being. I really don't know where you're getting this definition from. 
 
 We've gone around in circles enough times to get a good grip on the core issue here. I feel we understand clearly what the other person is saying, we simply disagree on what the definition of free will is. I say that free will is the ability to choose any option among all the available options. You say that free will is ability to act without influence or pressure from another person. The very simple solution to this dilema is to simply look up the definition of free will....
